findings.title: Write to Arbitrary Storage Location
findings.description: The smart contract allows writing to arbitrary storage locations, which can lead to unauthorized data manipulation and potential security risks.

findings.title: Missing Protection against Signature Replay Attacks
findings.description: The contract does not have sufficient protection against signature replay attacks.

findings.title: Weak Sources of Randomness from Chain Attributes
findings.description: The contract uses chain attributes as a source of randomness, which can be predictable and exploitable.

findings.description: The constructor of a contract has an incorrect name.

findings.title: Block values as a proxy for time
findings.description: Using block values (e.g., block.number or block.timestamp) as a proxy for time can be insecure and may lead to unintended behavior.

findings.title: Authorization through tx.origin
findings.description: Using tx.origin for authorization can lead to vulnerabilities as it can be manipulated by attackers.

findings.description: A delegate call is made to an untrusted callee, which can lead to unauthorized access or manipulation of data.

findings.description: The contract uses deprecated solidity functions which can lead to security vulnerabilities.

findings.description: The contract contains an unprotected SELFDESTRUCT instruction which can lead to unintended destruction of the contract.

findings.description: The contract has an unprotected ether withdrawal functionality.

findings.description: The return value of a call is not checked.

findings.description: A floating pragma is set (SWC-103)

findings.description: The compiler version used to compile the contract is outdated.

findings.description: N/A

findings.title: Function Default Visibility
findings.description: Functions with default visibility can lead to unintended access and manipulation of contract state.

findings.title: Contract has public burn function
findings.description: The contract contains a publicly accessible burn function.

findings.title: Deployer can transfer ownership
findings.description: The deployer has the capability to transfer ownership of the contract.

findings.title: Deployer can toggle purchase counter
findings.description: The deployer has the ability to toggle the purchase counter, which could lead to unauthorized changes.

findings.title: Deployer can start, stop, and end airdrop
findings.description: The deployer has excessive control over the airdrop functionality.

findings.title: Deployer can start, stop, and end crowd sale
findings.description: The deployer has excessive control over the crowd sale functionality, allowing them to start, stop, and end it at will.

findings.title: Deployer cannot mint after initial deployment
findings.description: The deployer of the contract loses the ability to mint new tokens after the initial deployment.

findings.title: Deployer cannot block users
findings.description: The deployer of the contract does not have the ability to block users.

findings.title: Deployer cannot pause contract
findings.description: The deployer does not have the capability to pause the smart contract.

findings.title: Deployer cannot renounce ownership
findings.description: The deployer of the contract does not have the ability to renounce ownership after initial deployment.
